0fa49f06-962a-48a8-9f64-c31bcd5b279a.content:
Symptoms can include...


  • Pain
  • Swelling
  • Bruising
  • Difficulty moving
  • Limb make look out of shape
  • Loss of strength
  • Visible protruding bone

44b7d9e4-e769-4689-b21e-158b6bf1cce7.content:
What Should You Do?


  1. Pad and support the injury
  2. Keep it secure with a triangular bandage if needed
  3. Cover any wounds
  4. Arrange for the casualty to go to hospital


Call 999 if:


  • there is bone visible
  • there is heavy bleeding
  • the patient looks to be going into shock
  • you cannot move the patient safely or without causing further injury

d77043f5-07b8-4f9a-a20e-8d78bb65b77f.content:
Bones have their own blood supply, so any broken bone will cause some bleeding internally. The worse the break is, and the larger the bone, the more dangerous a break can be.


If a patient loses a lot of blood through the break they can go into shock, especially if they are in a lot of pain or distressed. Help your patient keep calm by reassuring them and keeping them warm and comfortable.
